page.title: 05Tythe Barn, Edlesborough
page.content: The tythe barn at Church Farm, Edlesborough dates back to the end of the 15th century and is one of the oldest of its kind in the country. It would have belonged to the local vicar, who would have been a wealthy man. There were two threshing floors which no longer exist. These were made of clay or dung, mixed with water and beaten down hard. The villagers who flailed the corn worked by loop lights, narrow slits in the wall which produced a dim light. The whole barn measures about 180 feet by 30 feet and is reputed to be the largest barn in England. Just over 50 years ago there was a public outcry when the agent for the owner wanted to replace the thatched roof with galvanised sheeting. It was eventually relaid with tiles in 1930.
